bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, August 12, 1950

div1.p: Hench expresses regret that he was unable to attend Emilie Lawrence Reed's funeral, but hopes that Blossom Reed will now have time to rest. He informs her that he would be glad to receive and preserve any material of Emilie and Walter Reed's that she might come across in housecleaning, and that the University of Virginia, the Mayo Clinic and the Library of Congress have expressed interest in being permanent guardians of the Reed materials.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, August 12, 1950
div1.opener:
August 12, 1950
Mrs. Blossom Reed
Blue Ridge Summit
Pennsylvania
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
I am so very sorry that I was unable to pay my tribute to your
mother and father by coming to Washington. It would have been a real
honor to be one of the pall bearers. From what I have heard from General
Kean and others, the ceremony was a beautiful one and a very distinguished
one.

Now you, yourself, must get a long rest. The patience, understanding
and loyalty that you have shown to your mother for so many years was truly
remarkable and I know that it must have taken a great deal out of you. Now
you must think of yourself for awhile. Mary and I have been wondering
whether you plan to live in Blue Ridge Summit or whether you might move to
Washington. I should think that the peace and quiet of your old home might
be preferable, with visits to Washington.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
P.S.: If, in doing a certain amount of house cleaning, you come upon any
data concerning your parents which you would wish to have preserved with
the other material which you so kindly transmitted to me for my care, please
know that I shall be glad indeed to be custodian of it until such time as it
will be put in a permanent place. Three or four distinguished sources are
anxious to be the permanent guardians of it. As you know, the Librarian
of the Mayo Foundation and the Mayo Clinic is supposed to have a special
place for it in the new building of the Mayo Clinic. The Librarian of the
University of Virginia would be most happy to have it and one of the last
times I was in Washington one of the Chief Custodians of the Library of
Congress discussed the matter with me. Rest assured that all of this data
will be kept in perpetuity. I have thought that if it were possible, when
a final decision was made, I would try to have all the data microfilmed
or photostated so that complete sets of copies would be available to
the two institutions which did not receive the originals. In that way
perhaps all could be suited.
